newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Philippine peso rebounds as dollar demand eases.
newsitem.headline: Philippine peso rebounds as dollar demand eases.

text.p: * Turnover thins to $183.30 million in subdued trading
The Philippine peso recovered at close, settling at 26.337 to the dollar compared with Thursday's 26.342, after demand for dollars eased, traders said.
They added the steady selling rate of 26.345 of the Central Bank had discouraged banks from speculating against the peso. The bank was estimated to have sold $40 million in the morning.
"With the Central Bank at 26.345, there's no way the peso will go beyond that," one trader said.
The peso has been falling since Tuesday after domestic interest rates fell due to excess liquidity, reaching a 27-month low of 26.345 on Thursday.
Another trader said that steady inflow of foreign investment into the equities market had contributed to the supply side.
Value turnover thinned to $183.30 million from Thursday's record $446.30 million. Oil companies bought $20 million between 26.340 and 26.341.
Traders expected the peso to be range-bound next week as market skittishness has eased.
